required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Using Short Message Service (SMS) Reminders to Promote Health-Related Exercise in Older Adults
clinical_study.official_title: Promoting Health-Related Exercise Among Older Malaysians Using SMS Reminders. The Malaysian Physical Activity for Health Study (myPAtHS): A Randomized Controlled Trial

oversight_info.authority: Malaysia: Medical Ethics Committee, University Malaya Medical Centre

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of the study is:
1) To evaluate the efficacy and feasibility of an SMS reminder intervention for promoting an health-related exercise programme (myPAtHS) among older Malaysian adults, in a randomized controlled trial (RCT).
Hypothesis: Frequency and duration of the exercise programme execution will be higher for the SMS reminder condition compared to the programme only condition. The effect may be reduced from post- to follow-up measurement (24 weeks after baseline and 12 weeks after post-measurement) but all outcomes will remain significantly higher at 24 weeks.

clinical_study.study_design: Allocation: Randomized, Endpoint Classification: Efficacy Study, Intervention Model: Parallel Assignment, Masking: Single Blind (Subject), Primary Purpose: Prevention

primary_outcome.measure: Number of weekly myPAtHS exercise sessions.
primary_outcome.description: This will be assessed with an exercise diary and a single item.

primary_outcome.measure: Change of the number of weekly myPAtHS exercise sessions.
Weekly time spent doing the myPAtHS exercise programme.
primary_outcome.description: This will be assessed with an exercise diary and a single item.

primary_outcome.measure: Change in weekly time spent doing the myPAtHS exercise programme.

secondary_outcome.description: The International Physical Activity Questionnaire (short version) will be used to collect physical activity data.
The Exercise Self-Efficacy-Scale will be used to collect exercise self-efficacy data.
Grip strength will be assessed using the North Coast strength dynamometer (North Coast Hydraulic Hand Dynamometer, North Coast Medical Inc, Morgan Hill, California, USA).
Leg-strength will be collected using the 30 seconds chair-stand-test.

Acceptability of the SMS intervention will be examined after the intervention with a self-designed user-satisfaction questionnaire guided by former SMS and mobile health intervention studies. Questions on satisfaction with the programme, SMS characteristics, and overall evaluations concerning the delivery method for health-related exercise interventions will be included.

secondary_outcome.measure: Subjective intensity while doing the myPAtHS exercise programme.
secondary_outcome.description: This will be assessed with an exercise diary and a single item.

secondary_outcome.measure: Change in subjective intensity while doing the myPAtHS exercise programme.

arm_group.description: Participants randomized in this condition will not receive SMS reminders to execute the myPAtHS exercise programme.
Participants in this study arm will receive SMS reminders to motivate them to execute the myPAtHS exercise programme.

intervention.description: Participants will receive SMS reminders for their myPAtHS exercise programme compared to the other group where participants will only receive the myPAtHS exercise programme.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Mobile phone user
- Acceptable health that does not prevent exercise
- Acceptable command of the English language
- No engagement in a regular- structured exercise routine like gym training or other structured programmes
- Interest in an exercise programme
- Willing to attend scheduled follow-up sessions at 12 weeks (pre-post evaluation) and 24 weeks (post-intervention evaluation) after the first session
Exclusion Criteria:
- participants who have any medical condition or health concern that would restrict regular exercise based on one screening question. If this question will be answered with "yes" participants are advised to seek medical care.
